About 1540–50
Juan de Orna (active 1520–38)

The church congregation kissed a pax like this during the part of the Mass called the ‘Kiss of Peace’. Earlier paxes usually depicted Christ or the Virgin Mary. This one is more complex. It shows the Virgin giving a chasuble (priest’s garment) to St Ildefonso and probably comes from a Dominican convent.

About 1530
Probably by Juan de Orna (active about 1520-40)

The Latin word 'pax' means 'peace'. At the end of the Mass, the priest and congregation would kiss an object known as a pax to signify peace between Christians. This Spanish example shows St Ildefonso, a 7th-century archbishop of Toledo. He is said to have had a vision in which the Virgin Mary gave him a chasuble as a reward for his devotion.

PAX
Silver, parcel-gilt
Attributed to Juan de Orna (active about 1520-1540)
Spanish (Burgos); about 1530
Paxes were used to drinking the Mass as part of the 'kiss of Peace' ritual, signifying peace between Christians. The image on the pax would first be kissed by the priest and then by members of the congregation. The embossed relief on this pax depicts St. Ildefonso, Archbishop of Toledo (d.667) with the Virgin Mary who, according to tradition, appeared to him in a vision and presented him with a chasuble as a reward for his devotion. Behind this scene is a triptych showing the Crucifixion, with St. James the Greater and a kneeling bishop on the wings. On the pediment is the head of God the Father and above it the figure of a monastic saint.

fields.descriptive_line: Silver gilt depicting the Virgin giving an alb to St Ildephonsus
fields.physical_description:
[Pax] The pax shows Ildephonsus, the 7th century archbishop of Toledo receiving an alb (a long white tunic) from the Virgin Mary and two angels, beneath a round arch. The background shows the Crucifixion. At the base of the cross, to the left, the Virgin clasps her hands in mourning for her crucified son. To the right is a kneeling figure, his hands joined in prayer. This is probably the person who commissioned the pax. The round arch and its columns are decorated with applied plaques comprising: four blank shields, vases with leaf ornament, scrolling leaf patterns and the faces of winged cherubs. Above the arch, in the pediment, is God, his hand raised in a gesture of blessing. Projecting above him is a figure holding a book and dressed in a hooded monk's habit. This is probably St Bruno, the eleventh-century founder of the Carthusian order.
[Ornament] plaque, possibly silver, with the Agnus Dei (Lamb of god) attached to a plaque, possibly brass, cast in the form of rays of light

fields.marks: [Pax] Maker's and assayer's marks; town mark for Burgos
fields.public_access_description:
A pax (Latin: 'peace') is a small plaque with a representation of the Crucifixion or other religious subject on the face and a projecting handle on the back. Paxes symbolised the kiss or embrace which the priest celebrating mass passed to his subordinates, and which was then transferred to the congregation. The pax was kissed first by the celebrant, and then by others who received it (and kissed it) in turn.

This pax, and a plaque from another also in the Victoria and Albert Museum (V&A M.204-1956), were probably made for the Carthusian Monastery of Miraflores, Burgos, which was founded by John II of Castile in 1441 and, after a fire, rebuilt in 1453-1484. The maker of this pax, Juan de Horna (or Orna) (ca. 1475-1543) lived and worked in Burgos, the main centre for silversmithing in Castile (central Spain). Horna was praised by sixteenth-century writers for designing and decorating his pieces using motifs from the Classical past, at a time when the Classical style in Spain was arguably most evident in architecture and sculpture. Modern scholars have described this pax as a masterpiece of Renaissance Spanish silver.

fields.history_note:
[Pax] Juan de Horna (or Orna) (ca. 1475-1543) lived and worked in Burgos, which was the main centre for silversmithing in Castile (central Spain). In 1585 another silversmith, Juan de Arfe, included Horna in a list of silversmiths who used Classical motifs and designs in their works (Arfe, <u>De varia commesuracion</u>, Book IV, folio 3 recto).

This pax, and a plaque from another also in the Victoria and Albert Museum (V&A M.204-1956), were probably made for the Carthusian Monastery of Miraflores, Burgos, which was founded by John II of Castile in 1441 and rebuilt after a fire 1453-1484 (see Martín, 'Spain: Metalwork'). The Museum purchased Horna's pax £73.13.8 in 1864, from Francisco García Pérez, a silversmith in the Plaza Mayor, Salamanca.

Historical significance: The maker of this pax, Juan de Horna (or Orna) (ca. 1475-1543) lived and worked in Burgos, the main centre for silversmithing in Castile (central Spain). Horna was praised by sixteenth-century writers for designing and decorating his pieces using motifs from the Classical past, at a time when the Classical style in Spain was arguably most evident in architecture and sculpture. Modern scholars have described this pax as a masterpiece of Renaissance Spanish silver.

The decision to foreground the miracle of Ildephonsus on the pax may reflect the name of the donor (shown kneeling before the cross in the background). The choice may also have been influenced by the royal nature of the foundation where the pax was destined. Ildephonsus was archbishop of Toledo, Spain's principal See where kings of Spain were crowned (or crowned themselves). (For the significance of Toledo, see Linehan, 1993).
[Ornament] This plaque was added at the base of the pax at an unknown date in the object's history, perhaps as an expression of devotion, or to embellish the piece. It may also have represented an attempt to add monetary value to the pax. The pax with this plaque attached is illustrated in Riaño, Juan F. <u>The Industrial Arts in Spain</u>, p.33.
fields.historical_context_note: [Pax] A pax (Latin: 'peace') may be defined as 'a small plate of ivory, metal, or wood, with a representation of the Crucifixion or other religious subject on the face and a projecting handle on the back' (Cross and Livingstone, eds. <u>The Oxford Dictionary of the Christian Church</u>, sub nom. 'pax brede'). Paxes symbolised the kiss or embrace which the priest celebrating mass passed to his subordinates, and which was then transferred to the congregation. The pax was kissed first by the celebrant, and then by others who received it (and kissed it) in turn. Arfe, in his <u>De varia commesuracion</u> fols 28 verso - 29 recto, lays down a set of rules for the design and ornamentation of paxes. He stipulates that they should not have parts that protrude too far, so as not to harm the worshipper's face, and that the handle on the reverse should be wide enough to fill the holder's hand, but light enough to prevent the pax tipping backwards.
